message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest pelvic inflammatory disease, which can cause endometritis. Cervical motion tenderness and endocervical bleeding are also characteristic signs of pelvic inflammatory disease. Ovulatory dysfunction would not cause these symptoms, ectropion may cause spotting but not mucopurulent discharge, and endometriosis typically presents with dysmenorrhea and infertility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including painful and irregular bleeding, pain during intercourse, and cervical motion tenderness, suggest a diagnosis of endometritis. Ectropion is unlikely because the patient has a history of surgical sterilization, and ovulatory dysfunction is unlikely because the bleeding is not related to menstrual cycles. Endometriosis can cause similar symptoms, but cervical motion tenderness and endocervical bleeding are not typical findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings suggest endometritis, which is an infection or inflammation of the endometrium. Ectropion, ovulatory dysfunction, and endometriosis are less likely to cause the specific symptoms and physical findings described in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest the most likely diagnosis is Endometritis, an inflammation of the endometrial lining of the uterus that can cause pelvic pain, bleeding between periods, painful intercourse, and cervical motion tenderness. Ovulatory dysfunction and endometriosis can cause pelvic pain but not discharge or cervical motion tenderness. Ectropion can cause mucopurulent discharge but not bleeding or cervical motion tenderness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of painful bleeding between menstrual cycles, pain during intercourse, and postcoital bleeding, along with cervical motion tenderness and mucopurulent discharge, suggest that the most likely diagnosis is endometritis. Ectropion is cervical erosion, which can cause spotting but not the other symptoms. Ovulatory dysfunction refers to menstrual cycle problems, and endometriosis refers to the growth of tissue outside the uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest pelvic inflammatory disease or endometritis, which is supported by the presence of cervical motion tenderness and mucopurulent discharge. Ovulatory dysfunction and endometriosis do not typically present with bleeding between menstrual cycles. Ectropion may cause bleeding after intercourse, but is not associated with other symptoms mentioned in the case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including painful bleeding between menstrual cycles, pain during intercourse, and cervical motion tenderness with discharge, suggest endometritis. Ectropion and ovulatory dysfunction are less likely to cause these specific symptoms, and endometriosis typically presents with dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Endometritis is an inflammation of the endometrial lining of the uterus, and the patient presents with symptoms such as painful bleeding between menstrual cycles, pain during sex, and postcoital bleeding. Additionally, there is cervical motion tenderness and endocervical bleeding, indicating inflammation. Ovulatory dysfunction would not cause these symptoms, and ectropion and endometriosis typically do not present with these particular symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including painful bleeding between menstrual cycles and cervical motion tenderness, suggest the most likely diagnosis is endometritis. Ovulatory dysfunction typically presents with irregular menstrual cycles, ectropion is a common finding during pregnancy, and endometriosis may present with severe dysmenorrhea and infertility. The mucopurulent discharge can also be a sign of endometritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest the most likely diagnosis is endometritis, which is an inflammation of the endometrial lining of the uterus. The mucopurulent discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and endocervical bleeding are typical findings on physical examination for this condition. Ovulatory dysfunction, ectropion, and endometriosis do not typically present with the same symptoms as endometritis.
